description: In this series, we are going to learn the basics of using the command-line interface. If you have ever been scared when the cursor shows up on a seemingly blank screen or wondered what the Terminal or cmd application can accomplish, then stay tuned to learn the basics and increase your productivity.
descriptionMD: In this series, we are going to learn the basics of using the command-line interface. If you have ever been scared when the cursor shows up on a seemingly blank screen or wondered what the Terminal or cmd application can accomplish, then stay tuned to learn the basics and increase your productivity.
name: Getting Technical with the Terminal
subtitle: Comfort with the Command-line

episodes.description: In this series, we are going to learn the basics of using the command-line interface. If you have ever been scared when the cursor shows up on a seemingly blank screen or wondered what the Terminal or cmd application can accomplish, then stay tuned to learn the basics and increase your productivity.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.954 --> 00:00:15.455
Hello and welcome to
Getting Technical with the Terminal.

3
00:00:15.455 --> 00:00:19.379
Here to help us explain what this series
is all about is Mr. Justin Dennison.

4
00:00:19.379 --> 00:00:22.623
So Justin, what are we going
to be learning about in this

5
00:00:22.623 --> 00:00:25.428
series?
>> Well, the main goal of this series is

6
00:00:25.428 --> 00:00:30.367
to remove some of the fear that happens
when we remove the GUI interface, right?

7
00:00:30.367 --> 00:00:35.258
The graphical user interface from our
interactions with the computer and learn

8
00:00:35.258 --> 00:00:40.640
a little bit about how to create folders,
create files, move folders and files.

9
00:00:40.640 --> 00:00:44.590
Navigate around without the point and
click that we're all so

10
00:00:44.590 --> 00:00:48.300
use to in an effort, well,
to make us a little more productive, and

11
00:00:48.300 --> 00:00:52.080
to make us comfortable in case we ever
have to encounter that environment again.

12
00:00:52.080 --> 00:00:53.860
>> All right, well, that sounds exciting.

13
00:00:53.860 --> 00:00:55.650
So who is this intended for?

14
00:00:55.650 --> 00:00:57.530
What's our target audience here?
>> Well,

15
00:00:57.530 --> 00:01:01.740
this target audience is definitely,
you've never been in a terminal, right?

16
00:01:01.740 --> 00:01:04.904
You have never seen what
the command line interface or

17
00:01:04.904 --> 00:01:10.190
just this basic interface with no GUI
application, you've never seen it before.

18
00:01:10.190 --> 00:01:11.275
And if you're part of that,

19
00:01:11.275 --> 00:01:13.550
then that's our ultimate goal
is to make you comfortable.

20
00:01:13.550 --> 00:01:16.790
Allow you to understand what's going on,

21
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:21.730
and create a modicum of proficiency.
>> Well, it sounds like the perfect

22
00:01:21.730 --> 00:01:24.310
series for me because that's
where I would need to start.

23
00:01:24.310 --> 00:01:27.825
So is this geared towards
any type of certification or

24
00:01:27.825 --> 00:01:33.915
technical body that I can take a test for?
>> This is not certification-based,

25
00:01:33.915 --> 00:01:36.468
this is more about, well,
learning a little more so

26
00:01:36.468 --> 00:01:38.840
we can continue our progression, right?

27
00:01:38.840 --> 00:01:41.158
If you want to learn how to
become a proficient developer,

28
00:01:41.158 --> 00:01:43.918
well, you're probably gonna end up
in a terminal from time to time.

29
00:01:43.918 --> 00:01:47.462
And this is targeted towards you,
to dip our toes into the water and

30
00:01:47.462 --> 00:01:48.610
get things rolling.

31
00:01:48.610 --> 00:01:51.999
And if that sounds like a set of skills
that you're ready to embark on, well,

32
00:01:51.999 --> 00:01:52.949
I'll see you there.

33
00:01:52.949 --> 00:02:00.278
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore the terminal environment that are necessary to really dig deep into the development world. Justin provides an overview of the terminal, terminal emulator, and shell.
episodes.title: What is the Terminal?
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.173 --> 00:00:10.173
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:13.193 --> 00:00:15.615
Hello everyone and welcome to DevProTV.

3
00:00:15.615 --> 00:00:17.855
I'm your show host, Vonne Smith, and

4
00:00:17.855 --> 00:00:22.225
we are starting our new mini series on
getting technical with the terminal.

5
00:00:22.225 --> 00:00:26.415
And here to help us, tell us all about
what the terminal is, is the one and

6
00:00:26.415 --> 00:00:27.975
only Mr. Justin Dennis.

7
00:00:27.975 --> 00:00:29.195
And hello, how are you?

8
00:00:29.195 --> 00:00:30.325
>> I am doing fantastic, Vonne.

9
00:00:30.325 --> 00:00:31.200
How are you today?

10
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:34.790
>> I'm doing great, and I'm really
excited to start this little series.

11
00:00:34.790 --> 00:00:36.300
I know we got a couple episodes, but

12
00:00:36.300 --> 00:00:40.740
we're starting at the very beginning right
now, and so I have a question for you.

13
00:00:41.880 --> 00:00:43.070
What is the terminal?

14
00:00:43.070 --> 00:00:47.970
>> Well that is a great leading question
because, well, that's why we're here today

15
00:00:47.970 --> 00:00:50.760
because over the next few episodes
we're gonna learn how to use it.

16
00:00:50.760 --> 00:00:55.100
But before we can learn how to use it,
we should probably learn what it is.

17
00:00:55.100 --> 00:00:58.110
Now we're not gonna necessarily
be using the computer too much,

18
00:00:58.110 --> 00:00:59.390
I just wanna give you some back story.

19
00:00:59.390 --> 00:01:01.790
I wanna clarify some terminology,

20
00:01:01.790 --> 00:01:06.990
mainly because I tend to be
a little cavalier when I speak.

21
00:01:06.990 --> 00:01:10.815
And I do that because I know that
other people are cavalier, and so

22
00:01:10.815 --> 00:01:14.910
you'll hear the terminology a lot
of the times a way I use it.

23
00:01:14.910 --> 00:01:19.590
If you're a systems admin watching this,
then you might grit your teeth.

24
00:01:19.590 --> 00:01:23.376
But that's all right, because we're
developers, and we tend to be a little,

25
00:01:23.376 --> 00:01:25.081
a little off the cuff, so to speak.

26
00:01:25.081 --> 00:01:27.495
>> It's always good to
start off with vocabulary.

27
00:01:27.495 --> 00:01:31.845
And like you say, I do the same thing,
there's a technical definition and

28
00:01:31.845 --> 00:01:36.815
a real way I'm supposed to talk
about this, but I tend to use my own

29
00:01:36.815 --> 00:01:42.615
language or
not really use it too the letter, per se.

30
00:01:42.615 --> 00:01:46.532
And so that's why I always start off a lot
of my shows with, let me tell you what,

31
00:01:46.532 --> 00:01:50.370
this is the real thing, but
I'm gonna keep referring to it as x.

32
00:01:50.370 --> 00:01:53.600
>> And full disclosure,
this is not an exhaustive treatment,

33
00:01:53.600 --> 00:01:57.590
but this is just to give you a little bit
of back story to understand, well whoa,

34
00:01:57.590 --> 00:02:00.040
what we're going to be doing
in the subsequent episodes.

35
00:02:00.040 --> 00:02:02.350
So let's go ahead and
take a look at the screen.

36
00:02:02.350 --> 00:02:07.030
I actually have a, I don't do these a lot,
but this is a nice little talk.

37
00:02:07.030 --> 00:02:11.510
I should always step outside of my comfort
zone, as well as you should as well.

38
00:02:11.510 --> 00:02:13.770
That was a little redundant,
but that's all right.

39
00:02:13.770 --> 00:02:16.060
Just to make things work.

40
00:02:16.060 --> 00:02:21.345
It's almost like me and Vonne planned the
question, and totally coincidental though.

41
00:02:21.345 --> 00:02:22.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> So what is a terminal?

42
00:02:22.430 --> 00:02:27.780
It is a tool of many names, now keep
that in mind as I further discuss.

43
00:02:27.780 --> 00:02:29.230
But let's back up.

44
00:02:29.230 --> 00:02:31.260
Why do I say terminal?

45
00:02:31.260 --> 00:02:36.190
Well the terminal used to be how you
interacted with mainframe systems and

46
00:02:36.190 --> 00:02:39.460
other systems, and it was a physical
device, kind of like the one shown

47
00:02:39.460 --> 00:02:44.390
in this picture here, that you logged on
and kinda [SOUND ], and you did things.

48
00:02:44.390 --> 00:02:47.620
>> And didn't they call
those like dummy terminals?

49
00:02:47.620 --> 00:02:51.910
You're not on the machine itself,
you're just on this little

50
00:02:51.910 --> 00:02:56.860
satellite machine that`s connected
to a big machine over there.

51
00:02:56.860 --> 00:02:58.990
>> And those can definitely occur, yes.

52
00:02:58.990 --> 00:03:00.200
>> Okay.
>> A lot of times for

53
00:03:00.200 --> 00:03:04.110
these larger computers, when computers
were like the size of rooms, then

54
00:03:04.110 --> 00:03:08.740
that was probably the case, and you kinda
just pecked away, and you issued commands.

55
00:03:08.740 --> 00:03:13.700
And now these commands were built in and
run through what is known as a shell.

56
00:03:13.700 --> 00:03:18.860
A shell is the layer between the actual
hardware and kernel space and user space.

57
00:03:18.860 --> 00:03:21.950
Now what do I mean by kernel space and
user space?

58
00:03:21.950 --> 00:03:25.910
Well, kernel space,
the kernel is like a center,

59
00:03:25.910 --> 00:03:31.020
the goodness within these systems,
RAM operating systems that had these

60
00:03:31.020 --> 00:03:34.980
core set of functionalities that
were running behind the scenes.

61
00:03:34.980 --> 00:03:37.710
User space, though, you don't want to go
in there and go, well, let me turn this

62
00:03:37.710 --> 00:03:41.650
switch off, and this switch on, and
this switch off, and this switch on.

63
00:03:41.650 --> 00:03:44.920
Now I can see what's on the hard disk,
right?

64
00:03:44.920 --> 00:03:46.330
You don't want to do that.

65
00:03:46.330 --> 00:03:50.960
So it's exposed into users
space through the shell,

66
00:03:50.960 --> 00:03:55.150
the interface,
how we interact with those two regions.

67
00:03:55.150 --> 00:03:59.235
We interact through user
space into kernel space, so

68
00:03:59.235 --> 00:04:03.149
we issue commands [SOUND],
and well things happen.

69
00:04:03.149 --> 00:04:07.215
So this is technically a terminal,
however,

70
00:04:07.215 --> 00:04:10.968
before we talk more about the vocabulary,

71
00:04:10.968 --> 00:04:15.918
let's back up and
talk a little bit about those shells.

72
00:04:15.918 --> 00:04:19.070
So first generation shells
were fairly simplistic,

73
00:04:19.070 --> 00:04:21.760
there were only a few
commands that you could use.

74
00:04:21.760 --> 00:04:27.810
And the two prominent ones, there's
a whole bunch of these, and I actually use

75
00:04:27.810 --> 00:04:33.000
a few next gen or
latest generation that are alternatives,

76
00:04:33.000 --> 00:04:37.610
was the Mashey, could be saying
that wrong, and the Thompson shell.

77
00:04:37.610 --> 00:04:40.980
These were very, they were very strict,

78
00:04:40.980 --> 00:04:45.740
very limited in their use, and because
they were so limited, people were like,

79
00:04:45.740 --> 00:04:49.620
you know what, we actually need
a little more in functionality.

80
00:04:49.620 --> 00:04:53.050
We need a little more capabilities to
interact with the underlying operating

81
00:04:53.050 --> 00:04:54.830
system and hardware.

82
00:04:54.830 --> 00:04:57.000
And well we had the Bourne shell, and

83
00:04:57.000 --> 00:05:01.190
if you haven't noticed these are a lot
of times named after individuals.

84
00:05:01.190 --> 00:05:07.110
So the Bourne shell,
which a lot of times is just sh,

85
00:05:07.110 --> 00:05:09.330
you see sh, that's how I've seen it.

86
00:05:09.330 --> 00:05:12.790
I'm not saying that is
absolutely always the case,

87
00:05:12.790 --> 00:05:18.900
there may be alternative shells that are
also called sh depending on your system.

88
00:05:18.900 --> 00:05:21.030
And then there was the C shell.

89
00:05:21.030 --> 00:05:23.960
Now, I'm gonna stop here
at the second gen, and

90
00:05:23.960 --> 00:05:26.650
these were supposed to be
improvements on the previous slide,

91
00:05:26.650 --> 00:05:31.450
the Mashey and the Thompson cell, shell,
not cell, that's totally different.

92
00:05:32.650 --> 00:05:37.120
These two come along because you
need a little more programmability,

93
00:05:37.120 --> 00:05:43.188
you need a little more customizability,
you need a little more capabilities.

94
00:05:43.188 --> 00:05:47.210
And well, these came along, and
C shell was actually modeled,

95
00:05:47.210 --> 00:05:52.390
you'll see that abbreviated as csh, was
modeled after the C programming language,

96
00:05:52.390 --> 00:05:56.902
you could extend it by writing custom
functions, little routines, and things.

97
00:05:56.902 --> 00:06:02.130
And at this time,
C shell far outweighed the capabilities,

98
00:06:02.130 --> 00:06:04.010
just because of the customizability for

99
00:06:04.010 --> 00:06:08.620
programmers, being able to change things,
than the Bourne shell.

100
00:06:08.620 --> 00:06:12.350
But it still wasn't enough, and
people started getting traction, and

101
00:06:12.350 --> 00:06:15.960
they're like, well it'd be cool if it
could do this and that, and this and that.

102
00:06:15.960 --> 00:06:21.770
And there were still limitations, and I'm
kind of lumping these all together, these

103
00:06:21.770 --> 00:06:25.890
are not necessarily all occurring at the
same time, these are still a progression.

104
00:06:26.930 --> 00:06:28.830
But I wanted to give you an overview.

105
00:06:28.830 --> 00:06:35.770
We had the Tenex C-shell, tcsh, we had
the Bourne Again shell, which is bash.

106
00:06:35.770 --> 00:06:40.020
So it's funny that the Bourne shell,
and they did a play on words, and

107
00:06:40.020 --> 00:06:43.680
it's the Bourne Again Shell,
so that's abbreviated bash.

108
00:06:43.680 --> 00:06:46.720
>> Wait, because I hear you
guys talk about, you and

109
00:06:46.720 --> 00:06:51.230
Daniel are always talking about bash,
and that's what it stands for.

110
00:06:51.230 --> 00:06:53.910
>> Yeah.
>> Bourne Again Shell.

111
00:06:53.910 --> 00:06:58.740
Okay, now I have a little history of what
you all are talking about at the office.

112
00:06:58.740 --> 00:07:00.530
And I just go, Bash?

113
00:07:00.530 --> 00:07:02.155
I'm thinking like you're
bashing something.

114
00:07:02.155 --> 00:07:03.311
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't know.

115
00:07:03.311 --> 00:07:06.320
[LAUGH]
>> So Bash, it does roll off the tongue,

116
00:07:06.320 --> 00:07:10.840
and it has a fair amount of capabilities,
and this is kind of a standard.

117
00:07:10.840 --> 00:07:13.000
If you're in a Mac or a Linux system,

118
00:07:13.000 --> 00:07:18.280
a lot of times this is the default
shell that is available to you, bash.

119
00:07:18.280 --> 00:07:20.970
Bash offers a fair amount of capabilities.

120
00:07:22.010 --> 00:07:24.320
There are also other shells like Z-shell,

121
00:07:24.320 --> 00:07:28.980
which is, you can do everything that bash
can do, Z-shell more or less can do.

122
00:07:28.980 --> 00:07:33.640
But then there's additional things,
like, well I can

123
00:07:33.640 --> 00:07:39.070
easily alias, I have a little bit
different ways to customize how it looks.

124
00:07:39.070 --> 00:07:44.140
Like I have a z-shell installation
that has like clouds for the,

125
00:07:44.140 --> 00:07:48.780
on a command line interface,
which is usually just this black box.

126
00:07:48.780 --> 00:07:51.295
And so
there's some nice customizability, and

127
00:07:51.295 --> 00:07:56.308
Z-shell also supports some newer things,
like images.

128
00:07:56.308 --> 00:08:00.660
You can actually mess around with
images on the actual shell prompt,

129
00:08:00.660 --> 00:08:01.850
and it will display them.

130
00:08:01.850 --> 00:08:05.080
Now there are some assumptions there.

131
00:08:05.080 --> 00:08:09.920
It is more or less a preference
once you get to these three areas.

132
00:08:09.920 --> 00:08:12.700
And the final one is a fish shell.

133
00:08:12.700 --> 00:08:14.900
I haven't used that one a great deal, but

134
00:08:14.900 --> 00:08:18.450
it is very similar in its purpose for
Z-shell.

135
00:08:18.450 --> 00:08:22.880
It offers some extended capabilities,
and at this point, it's more about

136
00:08:24.690 --> 00:08:30.290
what you want, your preference than
necessarily a difference of capabilities.

137
00:08:30.290 --> 00:08:34.070
>> And just to make sure I'm following, so
we have the shell is what we're going to

138
00:08:34.070 --> 00:08:38.530
be using to talk to the hardware and
give it commands.

139
00:08:38.530 --> 00:08:40.710
>> Exactly.
We're gonna kind of proxy through

140
00:08:40.710 --> 00:08:43.950
the operating system using the shell,
and it's gonna do stuff, and

141
00:08:43.950 --> 00:08:48.900
it may look at our hard drive,
it may look at our network connections,

142
00:08:48.900 --> 00:08:51.800
it may just tinker around on our hardware.

143
00:08:51.800 --> 00:08:53.564
>> Based on what we tell it to do.

144
00:08:53.564 --> 00:08:54.741
>> Exactly.

145
00:08:54.741 --> 00:08:56.541
>> Okay.
>> And so the shell is the forward facing

146
00:08:56.541 --> 00:08:58.750
part that you are interacting with.

147
00:08:58.750 --> 00:09:02.190
Well, inside a terminal you are like,
hold up Justin.

148
00:09:03.660 --> 00:09:05.830
There's a terminal on my computer?

149
00:09:05.830 --> 00:09:07.520
Well, for the most part,

150
00:09:07.520 --> 00:09:12.410
there's terminal-like things, more
specifically, there's a terminal emulator.

151
00:09:12.410 --> 00:09:16.510
All right, it's not a physical little
chunk box that you carry around in

152
00:09:16.510 --> 00:09:19.520
a briefcase, those days are long gone.

153
00:09:19.520 --> 00:09:23.090
You have something that emulates
that machine that runs the shell

154
00:09:23.090 --> 00:09:25.970
that you can interact through alright.

155
00:09:25.970 --> 00:09:29.340
So terminal emulators,
you may have encountered them and

156
00:09:29.340 --> 00:09:32.370
didn't even know that you
were encountering them.

157
00:09:32.370 --> 00:09:36.826
Terminal emulators,
we have things like terminator,

158
00:09:36.826 --> 00:09:41.565
Konsole with a K, Terminal,
ConEmu, Gnome-terminal,

159
00:09:41.565 --> 00:09:46.521
iTerm2, Commander, guake,
there's also Kuake with a K.

160
00:09:46.521 --> 00:09:51.207
They have fancy names, but effectively
what they're trying to do is give you

161
00:09:51.207 --> 00:09:55.604
access to a shell program that you can
interact with, and it behaves like

162
00:09:55.604 --> 00:10:00.830
the terminal computer of old days of your,
but it's actually on your computer.

163
00:10:00.830 --> 00:10:03.580
>> So,
would these be considered applications?

164
00:10:03.580 --> 00:10:08.530
It's a program on your computer,
just like Word, or

165
00:10:08.530 --> 00:10:14.580
Text Editor, it's a program, and
it is emulating the terminal?

166
00:10:14.580 --> 00:10:18.950
>> Exaclty, so it is to provide you with
the same interface, it is an application,

167
00:10:18.950 --> 00:10:22.930
and it provides the interface to
the shell so you can interact with it.

168
00:10:22.930 --> 00:10:25.080
Now here's where I'm gonna stop and
back up.

169
00:10:26.700 --> 00:10:28.270
I said, what is the terminal?

170
00:10:28.270 --> 00:10:29.630
Vonne asked, what is the terminal?

171
00:10:29.630 --> 00:10:33.800
Technically, the terminal is this square
little box that was a physical machine,

172
00:10:33.800 --> 00:10:39.870
the interface to something else,
using a shell, on our computers,

173
00:10:39.870 --> 00:10:44.330
yours, mine, Vonne's, everybody who
have seen any of these programs.

174
00:10:44.330 --> 00:10:47.720
And yes,
Windows has some of these by default,

175
00:10:47.720 --> 00:10:51.170
if you've ever seen little screens
pop up during an installation,

176
00:10:51.170 --> 00:10:54.750
even if you've never actually got on it,
command prompt

177
00:10:54.750 --> 00:10:59.320
is technically a terminal environment
that gives you access to a shell.

178
00:10:59.320 --> 00:11:04.590
PowerShell opens up in
a terminal emulator to show you,

179
00:11:04.590 --> 00:11:07.570
I can type commands that
are Microsoft specific.

180
00:11:07.570 --> 00:11:12.820
So all of those, and I actually forgot,
I have a little bit of a bias.

181
00:11:12.820 --> 00:11:17.400
I forgot to include PowerShell
in the shells, that's on me,

182
00:11:17.400 --> 00:11:22.760
